title: 103_hr4238
content: The Act may be cited as the "Liberian Relief, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction Act of 1994". The Congress finds that the United States has a unique responsibility to Liberia due to historical ties and past support. It should continue to support UN peacekeeping forces to end the civil war that has caused significant loss of life and displacement. The US has an opportunity to help restore political order in Liberia by facilitating the cease-fire. The United States has a responsibility to Liberia due to historical ties and past support. It should provide substantial assistance for the reconstruction of the country. SEC. 495L. LIBERIAN CIVIL STRIFE ASSISTANCE. The United States should provide substantial assistance for the reconstruction of Liberia due to historical ties and past support. The President is authorized to provide assistance for civil strife relief, rehabilitation, and general recovery in Liberia on a grant basis. Priority for funding activities includes maximizing the use of private voluntary agencies, emphasizing emergency health projects, restoring schools and the education system, and supporting displaced children. The President is authorized to provide $45,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and $45,000,000 for fiscal year 1995 for assistance in Liberia. Up to $750,000 can be transferred for management support activities related to emergency humanitarian aid. The President is authorized to transfer funds to the Development Fund for Africa for longer-term rehabilitation activities in Liberia. Assistance under this section shall be provided in accordance with established policies and authorities. SEC. 4. MIGRATION AND REFUGEE ASSISTANCE: Authorizes $20,000,000 for fiscal years 1994 and 1995 for emergency relief for Liberian refugees and support for relief programs in bordering countries. Assistance to be provided through international relief organizations. The President is authorized to provide emergency food assistance for civilian victims of civil strife in Liberia, including rice, processed foods, and oils. Grants can be made to organizations to carry out this assistance. The President is authorized to provide emergency food assistance for civilian victims of civil strife in Liberia, including rice, processed foods, and oils. Additionally, $27,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal year 1994 and 1995 for assistance under this section. Up to $500,000 can be transferred for management support activities related to emergency food assistance for Liberia. The Administrator of the Agency for International Development shall ensure that $12,000,000 of local currencies generated under the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 in fiscal year 1994, and $12,000,000 in fiscal year 1995, are used for disaster assistance in Liberia. Funds available for disaster assistance in Liberia under the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act of 1954 may be used for general relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction purposes, including emergency food assistance, administered by the Agency for International Development. SEC. 6. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The assistance for Liberia under this Act is not subject to certain provisions regarding foreign assistance repayments. Relief and rehabilitation aid provided under this Act is in addition to regular assistance programs for the country. The Agricultural Trade Development Assistance Act of 1954 and the Assistance Act of 1961 provide food assistance. SEC. 7. REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Administrator of the Agency for International Development will compile a comprehensive assessment of Liberia's reconstruction, rehabilitation, and development needs, including infrastructure evaluation and resource projections. A detailed report must be submitted to Congress within 180 days. The President must submit a report to Congress analyzing the impact and effectiveness of US assistance for Liberia in the two preceding fiscal years by January 31, 1995 and January 31, 1996.
